body: Would it be possible to get POJOs used when the problem occurs? I suspect discrepancy could be due to buffering (when using `@JsonCreator`, or polymorphic types, for example).

Ok the problem is probably related to buffering needed by `@JsonCreator`, and linkage of parent context from buffer (which only holds a small set of tokens) to original parser (which has full parent stack). Worse, tokens are first added in buffer, but only replayed later on, with possibly different parent context -- that is, original parser may have been advanced to have different parent stack than when tokens were originally read.

I think what would be best here would be a small (as small as possible) reproduction; I can trouble-shoot parent linkage and see if problem can be fixed, or at least handling improved.
Is there something I can do to help you with that?
@pgunia Just a reproduction, unit test I could run to show it happening, would be big help. Of course anything beyond that wrt debugging where discrepancy happens would help too.

@cowtowncoder I've written some code that reproduces the issue. Take a look at the unit tests in this repo: 
https://github.com/pgunia/testStreamContext
@pgunia Ok. How do I build it? (seems to use Gradle, but I'm not too familiar with its use)

@cowtowncoder Yep, it's a gradle project. You should be able to import it into your preferred IDE directly via the GitHub Link. The IDE should take care of the rest. At least Eclipse and IntelliJ come with integrated Gradle support. The IDE will then download the required dependencies (only Jackson, take a look at build.gradle) and you should then simply run the Unit tests to see the behaviour. Let me know if you need additional info on this.
ok, I can do this. I just vaguely recall there being command-line tool (`gradlew`?) or a way to bootstrap from cli. But IDE is fine too.

One minor thing on test: instead of using `context.getParser()`, `handleUnknownProperty()` should use parser it is being handed. Context does not necessarily have the currently active one during handling of buffered entries (it only has the original, "main" parser).
Changing this does not eliminate the problem currently but does make behavior bit more consistent.

Note to myself: `TokenBuffer` needs to link context from `parser` it is being given for construction (if any).
But it may also be necessary to peel off one level, or otherwise adjust, since location is likely to be slightly off if simply using whatever exists. Plus there's the slight risk of messing up parser's context if not carefully checking that parent stack matches.

@pgunia Ok this took bit longer and was somewhat hairy to fix but I _think_ I got it resolved for `master`. Fix didn't make it in `2.9.0.rc3` but should be available via local build. I would appreciate independent verification (and reports if it's failing in some case(s)); but provided test passes, assuming I did not somehow mess it. Code is now changed so that contextual path from `TokenBuffer` goes back to (a copy of) original context, so it should retain correct information regarding logical position (nesting, current name), although not full location information (but only starting location of the first buffered token).
